intro: Brassica repanda var. turbonis, commonly known as the turban mustard, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, four-petaled flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and alternate leaves that are elongated and slightly serrated. Its flowers are usually yellow or pale yellow, and it produces small, round seeds in its dry, three-lobed pods. This species is often found in disturbed soils and is considered a weed in agricultural settings.
